title: Understanding Tenses in Grammar
narration: Welcome to this video on understanding tenses in grammar. We will explore how tenses help us understand the timing of actions and events making our communication more precise and clear. Let's dive in and unravel the complexities of tenses together.

title: What is Tense?
content:
Tense indicates the time of an action or event.
Helps us understand *when* something happens.
Key to expressing past, present, and future.
image_desc: Clock showing different times. Type: illustration
narration: Tense in grammar refers to the time of an action or event. It is a crucial element that helps us understand when something happens whether it's in the past present or future.

title: Main Types of Tenses
content:
Present Tense (Action happening now)
Past Tense (Action happened before now)
Future Tense (Action will happen)
image_desc: Timeline showing past, present, and future. Type: diagram
narration: There are primarily three main types of tenses in English grammar the present tense the past tense and the future tense.

title: Present Tense
content:
Simple Present – Facts or habits. *She writes a blog.*
Present Continuous – Ongoing actions. *She is writing a blog.*
Present Perfect – Completed actions with present relevance. *She has written a blog.*
Present Perfect Continuous – Actions started in the past and still happening. *She has been writing a blog for two hours.*
image_desc: Woman writing on a laptop. Type: photograph
narration: The present tense describes actions happening now. It includes the simple present used for facts and habits as in She writes a blog. The present continuous describes ongoing actions like She is writing a blog.

title: Past Tense
content:
Simple Past – Completed actions in the past. *She wrote a blog.*
Past Continuous – Ongoing action in the past. *She was writing a blog.*
Past Perfect – Completed action before another past event. *She had written a blog before lunch.*
Past Perfect Continuous – Ongoing past action before another past event. *She had been writing a blog for two hours before lunch.*
image_desc: A calendar with a past date circled. Type: illustration
narration: The past tense describes actions that happened before now. The simple past is used for completed actions such as She wrote a blog.

title: Future Tense
content:
Simple Future – Planned or spontaneous actions. *She will write a blog.*
Future Continuous – Ongoing action in the future. *She will be writing a blog.*
Future Perfect – Action completed before a future time. *She will have written a blog by tomorrow.*
Future Perfect Continuous – Ongoing action that will continue up to a future point. *She will have been writing a blog for two hours by noon.*
image_desc: A road stretching into the future. Type: illustration
narration: The future tense describes actions that will happen. The simple future is used for planned or spontaneous actions as in She will write a blog.
